instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Have a board in thats been dry-cleaned (see my post in the business forum), but there's no visible damage to the board: looks absolutely clean.
Have all normal readings on rails below <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>, but <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> is missing (0V). Cannot find any trace of corrosion anywhere.

Has a green and then orange light on the magsafeboard, but doesnt power on (i know that the fan spins only at higher cpu-temps)
Have tested with knowngood battery.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 4.97V

measured <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> on pin 2 of <CHIP>U8060</CHIP>, but get 0V

I don't fully understand how <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> is created.

any pointers?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: If <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> is missing the <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is missing, and this is gonna suck. Check traces to the SPI ROM and the SPI ROM termination resistors. Check clock voltage make sure it's 3.3 steady. Check <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin 8.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
thanks for the quick reply. i seem to be getting the shitty repairs lately.. for completeness' sake, here are the measured rails:
  [INDENT]<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.41V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.51V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 18.43V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.31V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER5V</SIGNAL> 12.51V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER3V3</SIGNAL> 12.51V

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S4_X239</SIGNAL> 0.0V (SPIKES a tiny amount to 0.04V when powersupply is started, but my multimeter is slow)

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 4.97V[/INDENT]
  

<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin 8 = 3.40V
all traces around <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> are pristine and resistors look brand new. any specific ones i need to measure?
clock voltage at pin 1 of <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> & pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR> is a steady 3.31V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: It could be pretty much anything. The usual suspects would be corrosion under <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>/<CHIP>U1900</CHIP>. Corroded traces and/or resistors going to <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> "termination resistors". Could be crap under SMC too. HiRes picture of those areas may also help for diagnosis.
